instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hello. Got this board here that had been messed on another shop. Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>. There were some missing components and some bad resistors underneath CPU and <RESISTOR>R1905</RESISTOR> was missing which I replaced. I get stable 8.56V on PPBUS and stable <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> power rail but no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>. Which signals exactly are needed to create it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> will stay low, until board exit from S5 state.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Now check if any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> reacts at the same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No, I get no pulses on ant <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: They probably killed the CPU in other service; if wasn't dead already.
